author: schone_wizard
content: ive read countless articles about it and cant quite put it together in my mind

author: foobar0x
content:
I can give it a shot, since so many others have been helpful to my understanding:

Current setup: first-price auction. Everyone bids what they are willing to pay, and pays that. This is inefficient because people end up overpaying, or underpaying and waiting.

New setup: base fee is determined based on the previous block size. If the previous block was larger than desired, fee is increased slightly. If the previous block was smaller than desired, fee is decreased slightly. This leads to an equilibrium where the average block size equals the target over time. Fees must be burned rather than paid to miners to prevent off-chain collusion to manipulate the fee.

author: schone_wizard

author: schone_wizard
content: why are miners opposing this scheme? how does it decrease their profits? and more specifically what does burning of fees do to ETH overall inflation? is new ETH still minted in every block to be paid to miners?

author: foobar0x
content: I'll do my best to not start a flamewar üôÇ Miners are opposed because now fees are being burned, not paid to them. This decreases the aggregate mining revenue. They still get the block reward but not the fees - the ETH block issuance is still the same, but now there's a deflationary pressure in the fee burning. So total ETH supply could go up or down after EIP-1559 (while now it only goes up).

author: barnabemonnot
content: that's a great eli5! i'll add the annoying eli10 nitpicking that users in the first price auction model do not bid their willingness to pay, and this is the key issue. they have to refer to the ambient level of bids to place their own, because since they pay what they bid, they try to minimise this value absolutely. it's a fact that FPAs induce bidders to bid below their true value. meanwhile in 1559 users can actually set their willingness to pay to the fee cap attribute of the transaction (though in practice i am not even sure they need to, vs a reasonable wallet default). since basefee floats, it means users are guaranteed to pay _at most_ their willingness to pay and at the same time _the lowest rate possible at the time of inclusion_, thus removing the incentive to underbid and to refer to other bidders to decide your bid

author: foobar0x
content: Yep, a first-price auction has this weird dynamic where you both overpay (relative to what is necessary for inclusion) and underpay (relative to your willingness) simultaneously because of the bid mechanics.

author: barnabemonnot
content: you can set the fee cap, which is one parameter of 1559 transactions, to the highest price you are willing to pay. as long as transaction pools decide to keep your transaction around, you are still potentially eligible for inclusion later

author: barnabemonnot
content: however, there were discussions that transaction pools in general shouldn't be responsible for keeping your inventory. the spirit of 1559 is that it quotes you a price (basefee + miner fee) and you can either take it or leave it

author: barnabemonnot
content: if basefee makes transactions $100 and you say you don't want to pay more than $0.10, i think it's reasonable that you shouldn't expect the pools to keep your transaction

author: barnabemonnot
content: keeping your transaction is a drain on both their memory and the p2p network on which transactions are rebroadcast

author: barnabemonnot
content: i expect pools would implement weak limits, such as "if your fee cap is less than 50% of the current basefee, we'll drop you"
